data.title: 270th FA Bn. ETO. WWII
data.meta_description: i have been doing some fact finding about the 270th for the last few months and am wondering if anyone on here  has info about this unit?   This was my Grandfathers
data.text:

This list was put together by a laundry list of different sources (Unit Rosters, Obituaries, AARs, etc..) but as far as I know this is approx 90+% of the men assigned to the 270th at one time or another.

Please feel free to correct me on any mistakes or any additions / info you may have about the unit.

Brian

You've come up with a remarkable collection of documents. To create a complete roster like you want to do is not impossible, but will take considerable resources in both time and, unless you go to the National Personnel Records Center yourself by appointment, money.

I compiled a roster for my grandfather's unit, focusing on the overseas time. I started with having a private company in St. Louis digitize some rosters from 1942 and 1943. As has been pointed out, the Army destroyed most of its rosters from 1944 and 1945. However, there is a workaround: the morning reports. They are exceptions based, so they won't mention a solider unless something changed. However, using the December 1943 roster as a starting point, if you obtain the morning reports from all batteries in the battalion, you will be able to follow soldiers as they come and go. I think you'll also find that there are many more names than you expected, because men transferred in and out. In three years of overseas service, my grandfather's unit had about twice as many people serve in total as the T/O&E authorized for any one time. Turnover in combat units would presumably be even higher.

Maybe Fold3 will eventually digitize all WWII morning reports, as they allegedly hope to do. Otherwise, you're talking about many days of work at NPRC (if you can even get an appointment) or thousands of dollars for a private company to digitize everything for you.

Lowell. Thanks for the reply. I started this journey to give my mom a small glimpse of what my Grandfather did in the war. He never spoke of it (like most veterans of that generation). It has since snowballed into what I have today. 648ea names. War time TOE strength was 475ea. Like you mentioned, lots of turnover.

I am slowly piecing together a roster. I have gathered names from unit rosters and AARs obtained from NARA and NPRC, obituaries found on the internet, books and pamphlets written by guys in the unit, plus help from forums like this one. I have not taken the time to scour all of the morning reports. I have a few, but not all. Would hate to spend that much money to only find names already known.

I hope this helps others to understand a little bit more of what their father, grandfather, uncle, neighbor, etc.. did in the war.
